description:
This is a great spot if you're still craving dessert after scarfing down some delicious Asian food in the area. The soft serve portions are pretty small. If you're concerned you can always share with a friend. 

I got the POPCORN SOFT SERVE. I like having a good crunch with my ice cream, and this did just the trick. There is plenty of popcorn on the top as well as in the center (genius). They drizzle caramel in it as well to give it an added flavor. The soft serve was perfectly creamy. 

I would definitely come back to try some of their other flavors.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Stumbled across Honey Creme after eating dinner across the street. My boyfriend and I ordered the Strawberry Milk Tea and a Cotton Candy Affogato. 

I thought the drink and soft serve was ok. However, my boyfriend loved it. Not sure if its because he loves ice cream, cotton candy, and coffee. But, he loved it. He pretty much devoured the soft serve and I probably ate a couple bites. 

I would return if I was in the area, but I probably wouldn't go out of my way to return back. The place is worth a try if you are in the area.
author: Kathleen L.

description:
I've seen this place all over, and finally came down to try it. I came here with a couple of friends on a Saturday afternoon around 2pm. There were only a few seats, but it was empty so there was no problem getting a spot to sit. We asked what flavors she recommended and she told us the most popular was the honey or the honeycomb. 

We got the honeycomb ($4.75) and added boba ($0.50). Honestly, it was kind of underwhelming. The ice cream was creamy, but had no flavor whatsoever, unless paired with the honeycomb. There was only one chunk of honeycomb so it was hard to spread it with the rest of the ice cream. I wish they layered honey in it (though I guess that's why they have the honey flavor you could pick). It melted pretty quickly (but I guess that's understandable with soft serve). The boba was good and soft, so I would definitely get that as a topping again. Also, a bit pricey for the size of the dessert. 

I would be open to giving this place another try if I was in the area, but I would probably get a more flavorful option, like Chocolate or Oreo.
author: April L.

description:
Honey Creme is an international chain from South Korea and they've started a slow expansion to the US with San Francisco being their first West Coast outpost and Milpitas being their second. 

It's a small shop located in the Sunset district and is a few blocks from San Tung.  The interior has limited seating but it's clean and bright and features a large, easy to read menu highlighting their signature soft serve options and their flavored ice cream cone choices.  Our order:

Honeycomb Ice Cream - $4.50. it's a beautiful dessert with luscious swirls of milk soft serve mixed with ribbons of honey and a very nice and impressive cube of real honey comb on top.  Flavors are delicious and it's easy to see why this shop has the hype behind it.  The soft serve isn't too sweet and the honey matches very well with everything tasting fresh, organic and high quality.   Several other patrons tried the cotton candy version and it's also impressive and great for sharing.  

If there's one caveat, it's that the close-up photos all make the desserts look larger than they are in real life.  You really don't have a good reference in the store but if you can see their cone selection, you notice how petite the desserts are and the cup choices are similar in size. 

Overall, even with the smaller than expected size, I loved the flavors and thought it worth the cost.  I look forward to Honey Creme's continued expansion and will look out for a Peninsula location if they have that in their future. 

Honey Creme accepts credit cards including Amex.
author: Randy F.

description:
This place is a little pricey, but it easily became one of my favorite dessert shops to visit whenever I'm in SF. It's a small shop and is rarely busy (perhaps due to minimal seating?), but the quality is great.

My go-to drink is the honey green tea with 75% sweetness. I recently tried the honey milk tea and that was pretty bomb too. I appreciate how the tea flavor is still apparent in all drinks they make.

One of the unique things about Honey Creme is their soft serve ice cream. The earl grey with boba is PERFECTION. Boba is well cooked with a nice chewy consistency and the earl grey has a fragrant flavor.

Parking can be really difficult since it's metered or street parking. My boyfriend usually drops me off and I run in to order. We're from Sacramento and we've filled up two stamp cards now... so yeah, we love it!

Bonus: There's a restroom! Yay!

Definitely visit if you're in the area!
author: Karen T.

description:
Okay dessert place in Irving street

I got ice-cream with honey comb ($4.75). It's soft serve icecream with honey comb. Nothing special. For the price, I'd rather go to gelato place nearby lol If you've never had one before, it's worth a try though!
author: Clare L.

description:
One of the best and yummiest soft serve places in SF!

I really like Honey Creme because their soft serves are not too sweet, and although it doesn't look like much, it is actually pretty dense and filling. They also have a lot of different items on their menu like smoothies and coconut pudding. 

If you are unsure of which flavor to get, you can ask for a sample. The cashier/worker was super nice and patient. I decided to go for the earl grey soft serve (their new seasonal flavor) and my friend went with the original with a shot of espresso. The espresso and the slightly melted soft serve, made it taste like coffee soft serve. 

Be sure to get a stamp card too, so you can save up and get that free soft serve!
author: Kristine P.

description: I had been wanting to try this spot for a while, I really liked the concept of this place and the desserts looked really tasty in the photos! I ordered the soft serve with rainbow sprinkles and a honeycomb for about $5. When I received my order, I was surprised by how small it was compared to the way it looked on the menu photos. I neglected to convey that in the photo I took, but for lack of a more uniform comparison- it looked the size of a Starbucks small coffee cup in the menu photo and came out a similar size to the Starbucks espresso cup. Main reason for the low stars- the actual soft serve was bland and completely nothing special! I've had better from a fast food chain. :/ It looks good in the photo I took, but that's no substitute for actually BEING good!
author: Shav S.

description:
Service with a smile. Plus delicious soft serve. 

I returned today after visiting shortly after they first opened. I then tried the organic mixed grains. It's a subtle combination of savory and sweet.

They now offer tea, shakes and slushes. The choice of milk is whole or half and half. I ordered a matcha latte with half and half. It was nicely balanced - not too sweet or bitter. 

I will return to try other options - probably the honey comb with the soft serve, since I noticed many people like it. They also offer seasonal flavors of the soft serve, with a great variety of toppings. Visit when you're in the area!
author: Carol W.

description:
My wife is a huge fan of HoneyMee from LA.  So naturally, we decided to check the place out (on National Ice Cream Day, nonetheless).  The thing that makes Honeymee is delicious is the flavor of the soft serve combined with the great tasting honey (and honeycomb).  

The flavor of the ice cream was lackluster, making us question why we were paying $4.50 for McDonald's level ice cream.  Also, it's an extra $1 for the honeycomb.  I can appreciate the store supporting our bee's, but that's a bit steep.  

I tried the cereal ice cream, which wasn't bad, but again, for the price that we were paying, I'd want something better than "not bad".  All in all, a solid place, but I wouldn't make the trek out there, unless David Chang decided to feature it in an episode of Ugly Delicious.
author: Jason L.

description: The soft serve was mediocre, you get overcharged for the tiniest square of honeycomb and the cotton candy topping is course and dense. Staff is nice, but passing next time.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
Thought the soft serve here was very similar to The Milk Bar in NY. I ordered the honeycomb on the original soft serve. It was my first time trying honeycomb but I had some expectations on how it would taste and feel. The honeycomb in everyone's photos here on yelp looked goopy and moist but the one I got was kinda dry:( Once the topping was gone, I got kinda bored with the soft serve alone so I tossed the rest. It just wasn't sweet enough. My friend had the dark chocolate which was good... but don't think either was worth $4.50.

We came in after dinner on a Thursday night. Parking was easy, found a spot right out front. The seating is limited. The place is pretty small. There was a group of very loud teens we had to sit like elbow to elbow with. But once they left it was alright.
author: Mary R.

description: I have been meaning to try this place because of their tea soft serve and boba! The seasonal flavor i got to try was the earl grey tea soft serve (not sure if they had black tea before.)  The soft serve tasted just like earl grey tea and the boba was perfectly cooked! I do have to say, the soft serve was a tiny bit icy but I didn't mind it as I have been craving tea flavored soft serve for awhile. I'm not sure if the other menu items are like this, but I would still come back to this place is they make the season flavor a permanent menu item!
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
Two things I'm a sucker for: Soft Serve and honeycomb. And MATCHA. Ok 3 things.

Thats what I had:

MATCHA SOFT SERVE w/HONEYCOMB - $4.25
I really enjoyed this refreshing desert. Don't expect it to look as green as the photo, and you probably wouldn't want it to, haha.  The honeycomb gives it it this extra texture of sweetness, on Top of the subtly sweet and creamy matcha soft serve. 

This place doesn't seem to get so busy so there's plenty of room to sit and enjoy your soft serve!  The staff is friendly and I enjoyed my time here.
author: Tu-Anh N.

description: The honeycomb cone was delicious and just the perfect portion size.  I love me some honeycomb!
author: Roger E.

description: Surprisingly a great place for boba. I loved my drink and actually was pleasantly surprised having their soft serve. Parking around this place is horrendous just like any SF establishment but their drinks and ice cream made up for it many time over. I didn't enjoy their avocado drink that much though. Try out their soft serve, it's good.
author: Jan R.

description:
Came here and got the honey soft serve. It really was just ok ice cream and there was honey drizzled around. Considering that was their speciality, really expected something special. The portion is also really small. The photos make it look much larger than it really is.

All in all, I feel like this is just basically Dairy queen soft serve with honey.
author: Victor D.

description:
Pretty solid boba and dessert place for San Francisco.

Came here and got a bunch of drinks with Honey in them. they didn't disappoint.

I tried the cereal ice cream and it was just okay, but definitely come by for some decent (very sweet) drinks and dessert!
author: Andrew T.

description:
I love cereal milk from Milk Bar so it was such a pleasant surprise to see cereal milk at Honey Creme! However, it honestly can't compare to Milk Bar. At first I thought it was great Bc it's so creamy! But I wish the soft serve was a little sweeter. 

But I love the organic grain mix!! It's super delicious! I'll just stick with that from now on :)
author: Janice H.

description: I had the earl grey and milk soft serve swirl with honey drizzled on top. The froyo wasn't very sweet, which I loved, and it was really fluffy. Don't think I've had that texture of froyo before but I liked it. The honey flavor was pretty subtle. My friend ordered their matcha boba tea and thought it was too sweet and not enough matcha flavor. I'll check it out again when they change their seasonal flavor.
author: Alice W.

description:
Walked by Honey Creme & Tea after dinner close by. My girlfriends and I wanted a small treat and decided to go in after seeing all the delicious photos/selections on the menu and how it reminded us of HoneyMee.  We shared one Himalayan Salt Dark Chocolate. The soft-serve was smooth and milky. The milk flavor was a little too empowering for my liking and I was pretty much finished with my portion after 3 scoops. 
The shop doesn't have many seating options. There is a long bench against the front window to enjoy. Luckily, we were able to find space on the bench to sit and eat on a Friday night.
author: Michelle S.

description:
The One Where Sandy Bought Soft Serve in the Cold.

So... this place is aite.  I think I was just surprised with how small the serving was for the price (I mean, I could have gotten a pint of Magum at Safeway).  Regardless, the soft serve was still tasty.  I had the Dark Chocolate and my hubby had the honey comb.  The store uses something similar to the "magic shell" you can buy in stores where it turns the liquid dark chocolate to a hard shell upon impact with the cold.  It was a nice touch. 

The honey comb is probably my favorite because what's not to love about a honey comb?!  

Was it the best soft serve I'd ever had? No.  Would I come back again? Probably not.  With so many other dessert joints, I will only come back if my friends from out of town asks to go.
author: Sandy H.

description:
Love this place. It's expensive. But it's luxury comfort food with soft serve and honey. 

We came here Sunday night right before close and the two gals behind the counter served us up right.

I ordered the honey comb, and the ice cream assembler didn't put my honey comb on top of the cone well and it plopped on the ground. She gladly gave me a new honey comb piece. 

Their creations are so trendy and instagram worthy. 

My friend also got the cotton candy topping which tasted like honey and was to die for. 

HONEY HONEY HONEY!!! I love this place. You've got to come here anytime you come to the city. No complaint, always perfect.
author: William R.

description:
Under "Ice Cream", they have listed a variety of flavors, or so I thought. Ordered the "Dark Chocolate Ice Cream", but instead received vanilla soft serve dairy with dark chocolate fudge....for $5!

Turns out this place only sells 2 flavors of "ice cream" and everything under "ice cream" are merely toppings. Told them they need to rename it to "Ice Cream Toppings". The last time I was this disappointed, I purchased Vietnamese springs rolls for $7 and two Chinese egg roll sized (cut into 6 pieces) was served.
author: Ben P.

description:
Honey Creme & Tea is your standard soft serve ice cream place around the corner. It is 'instagrammable' but other than that I don't think it has the big 'it' factor compared to the other ice cream places in SF.

Location: It's on Irving where there are plenty of asian food places. I came after studying at the UCSF library. Small intimate shop and there are seats and tables inside. 

Size and price: Pretty much as everyone said here, the serving size is smaller than it appears on camera. Take your average milkshake that you get a your fast food place and cut it half for a visual representation. It is $4.50 for a cup with toppings. There is a picture of the menu here.
author: Amica J.

description:
Trick of the eye... not everything instagrammable actually tastes delicious I have come to learn.

Basically, I'd rather pay $1-2 for a McDonalds cone than eating an overpriced but beautiful treat here. The consistency definitely veers on the creamier side. I think the soft serve itself lacks flavor (not sweet enough for me I think!)

Around $4.50 each. Pricey but if you're looking for something cold, it beats paying $8-9 for Froyo across the street.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Honey Creme is not to be confused with the popular LA chain. The store is very cute, and the service is nice, but the frozen yogurt is pretty mediocre and the avocado smoothie was not tasty.

* Avocado Smoothie - 2.5 stars: Tasted really thick and bland. Boba was not good.
* Matcha frozen yogurt - 3.5 stars: Pretty good but prefer Matcha Love in San Jose. They have one seasonal rotating flavor. 
* Original - 3 stars: As most described, this is pretty bland and probably intentionally so because it is served with honey. 

Cute IG-worthy spot, sub-par frozen yogurt.
author: Jess C.

description: Great soft serve in Inner Sunset! I came here with a friend on a Friday at around 2pm. The place was pretty empty, so we decided to eat there. We shared a honey soft serve, and it was delicious! Just enough sweetness without it being overly sweet. And since we both weren't that hungry, it was the perfect size. While we were eating there, they were also playing some kpop (for all you kpop fans out there), and the service was quick and efficient. Overall, this is a great place to grab some dessert, and I would definitely come back and try their other flavors!
author: Lisa C.

description: The affogato soft serve combines creamy soft serve & great coffee flavor. Personally think it's one of the best items on their menu. The size is not too big where you feel overwhelmed either. The Oreo shake with boba is also a good creamy drink for those who enjoy cookies & cream flavor.
author: Nicole M.

description:
I was so stoked to try this out since I didn't get the chance to the last time I was in SF. But it did not live up to my expectation. 

First of all, it's a very small shop and I think it was not so easy to spot while you're just driving past. There are also no tables for you to sit, so it is definitely a grab and go place. 

They are famous for their soft serve using organic milk and the instafamous thing to order is with the honey comb of course. So I got the matcha, milk swirl topped with honey comb. The ice cream was smooth and soft, not very sweet at all and the taste was very mild (not too milky  if you know what I mean). And the honey comb pairs really well to complement the ice cream with some sweetness to it! However, the honey comb is pretty small so you really have to portion it if you want to have eat it throughout your ice cream. For the matcha flavor, I really wish that it would taste more like matcha. The taste was just very mild.

I also got the avocado milkshake which was okay. Nothing too special.
author: Dream-Suphada L.

description: Came here for their seasonal flavor, Earl Grey. The soft serve was pretty good. My friend loved it! I would try their other flavors if I was in the area again.
author: Elaine G.

description:
Honey Creme is my favorite soft-serve place in SF - my go-to order is the Cereal Milk (in a cup), though I've also tried the Organic Grain and Honeycomb soft-serve and would highly recommend those too.

Unlike other ice cream places, Honey Creme's soft-serve is way more milky (which I love!), and not too sweet. It doesn't melt too fast either, so no need to hurry to gobble it down. The texture is creamy and smooth and pairs well with honey/caramel syrups.

I usually come here once a week after getting pizza at Arizmendi's around the corner. Perfect place for a quick after-lunch dessert!
author: Yuan J.

description: Me and a bumble BFF was looking for a dessert the other day and found Honey creme usa! It was a warm day in the city so having something that will cool us off is a great idea! We love their soft ice cream because it's light! They have Earl Grey as their seasonal flavor it's really good and The affogato is good too!
author: Emily Ann F.

description:
We love honey and ice cream- have had it a few different ways- this was nothing special- got two ice creams- one honey drizzle and the other just honey comb- wish this was just one option- honey drizzle with a piece of comb- I also was looking forward to the green tea ice cream with honey comb but I guess it was seasonal. Seems like a popular thing right now and the other flavors on the menu shadow next to the option of green tea. The cotton candy is a cute option. 

It was really hot and muggy in the building and wish we had access to like water or something - a lot of ice cream places do... maybe it's an SF thing. 

Lastly was sorta dirty the counters were dirty and the tables were dirty- the display case kept confusing customers. Twice while I was in there people kept trying to buy items that look like they are for sale in their case but weren't.

Anyway- I'd probably look for something else to try before coming here again.
author: Jennafer F.

description: Been wanting to try this place for a while, but sadly, it was a disappointing experience. The portions are really small for what you get, and the soft serve is extremely bland. I generally prefer my ice cream to be semi-sweet, but seriously there was no flavor at all. There was a bubbly woman working behind the counter, but she wasn't very helpful when it came to helping me decide what flavors to try. I let her know that it was my first time, but still no suggestions, even when I asked for some. I ended up just ordering an original on a cone and an Oreo soft serve.  Also being a honey lover, I was curious to see what the honey flavor tasted like, so I asked if I could try a small sample. She seemed a little confused and unwilling to offer me a sample. But once she finally did it was a tiny droplet. Seriously the tiniest droplet ever LOL. Honestly, I was taken aback at how stingy this business was with even a small sample of honey. Most ice cream places will offer you at least a sample or ask you if you want to try a flavor, but forget about it at this place. I found that surprising and off putting. Having ice cream is supposed to be a cheerful experience, but certainly not here.
author: Phan ..

description: It was ok but really not that much better than soft serve anywhere else. Definitely not amazing. The honey and honeycomb is great but the main thing is the soft serve so meh... the honey would go great on Salt and Straw ice cream...!
author: J D.

description:
Sigh, I really wish this place served ice cream as good as it looks.

We came here after a long and hot afternoon wandering the Japanese Tea Gardens. I ordered the option with the Caramel Popcorn on a cone.

Honestly, I should have gotten one of the cup options. The cone itself was brittle and weak - after a couple licks, the ENTIRE TOP LITERALLY BROKE OFF. I wasn't able to finish my cone because the top (that was holding the bulk of the ice cream) literally broke off into my grungy hand. I just threw the remainders of my sad forlorn ice cream in the trash. 

The guy behind the counter saw me throw my ice cream in the trash. He then said "Oh i was going to offer you a cup for your fallen ice cream".  Obviously it was too late BECAUSE I JUST THREW IT IN THE TRASH, DUH. I'm not sure if this is terrible of me to say, but I almost expected/hoped he would offer to make me a new cone. It was obvious that I barely had any before the entire thing broke off and went into the trash. Wouldn't it be better for them to spare an extra scoop of ice cream in exchange for a better Yelp review? Because that service would have definitely helped.

The milk ice cream itself was only tasty on the first few licks. After a while, it just became bland and tasteless. The Popcorn was a bad idea because it kept falling on the ground as the ice cream melted. All around just a bad design.

Skip this place - it might look nice for the photos, but you're not getting quality desserts. Also, don't be fooled by the colored cones on their menu. ALL their cones are the normal boring beige color.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Sooo yummmyy. It was my first time here and I tried their new "Cereal Milk" flavor, which was layered with cereal bits and caramel. My friend got the plain soft serve with honey and that one was really delicious too. 

The only reason why I'm not giving it 5 stars is because service was a bit slow. There was a family in front of us that had already ordered (who knows how long they'd been there) and was waiting for two bags of cotton candy. My friend and I got our orders the same time they got their cotton candies, but even that took a while. To be fair, there were only 2 people working but it looked like they were taking their sweeeet time. 

Regardless of time, it was still good and I'd probably come back. Just don't expect to get your ice cream right away.
author: Vivian L.

description:
I've been to this place a handful of times since I live walking distance, and it's not a place I would rave about, but it's not bad. 

I've tried the original flavor with honeycomb, the affogato, the matcha soft serve with honeycomb, and the original with grains. First of all, the original flavor is pretty plain. I appreciate that it's not overly sweet, but I would have to say it's more on the bland side, and out of all the toppings I've tried so far, the affogato would have to be my favorite because the espresso makes up for the bland flavor. The honeycomb is aight and the mixed grains is the worst so just don't get that one. I honestly didn't know what I was thinking when choosing that. The mixed grains added to the blandness of the soft serve if that's even possible and made it dryer. Lastly, the matcha wasn't matcha enough. From the pictures on their menu, I expected it to be more green in color, but whatever as long as it tastes good, right? Well, the matcha flavor was hardly noticeable either! Not super impressed but like I said before, they're not bad and I would probably go back. It is in the pricier side of things because each soft serve is $4.50 - $5 and the portions are smaller but I don't mind that part too much.
author: Christina C.

description:
The first warm day of the year in SF and I found myself walking home from work and needing a co treat.

I've walked by Honey Creme & Tea since it opened, but today it called to me!

Walked into an empty store front and was greeted by a small, clean space with a cheery employee.

They have a large digital display of their offerings and The moment I saw Affogato I knew I must have it!

My order was served up quick. I first tried the soft serve by itself. A white velvety soft Creme with a very mild, not too sweet flavor. Then I dug down to that still slightly warm expresso and spoon to mouth... BOOM I was hooked. 

Spoonful after spoonful of the glorious Creme and coffee until the bitter end. 

Loved it! I'd stop in again for sure.
author: Meghan L.

description: Excellent excellent excellent. Both flavors, earl grey and milk, are extremely delicious and fresh tasting. Every flavor looks bomb. They serve one with fresh honey comb. We tried the half and half Oreo, the milk and cereal, and the milk with rainbow sprinkles. Everyone of them was bomb. But my absolute favorite is the coconut pudding. So fresh and light and yummmmm. Want to try all the flavors!!!
author: Alex K.

description: Cute spot with very instagrammable desserts. I got the classic vanilla soft serve with honey and while it was more or less what you'd expect, it was the perfect sweet treat at a pretty reasonable price. Wish we had one of these on the East Coast!
author: Cheng X.

description: I always end up coming here on my cheat day for their earl grey soft serve ice cream or grapefruit tea when I want something refreshing.
author: Pee W.

description: To be honest, I wanted to like this place more than I actually did. I'm the kind of person who desperately craves soft serve ice cream, so I stopped by to get some one night. I think the soft serve itself doesn't really have much flavor and it leaves a bit of a weird aftertaste. Also, the portion is super small for the price you pay. I did however think the mango slush with lychee jelly that my boyfriend got was quite good! So, I'd probably go back for the slush but it's definitely not one of my go-to places.
author: Claire C.

description:
I love love Love Honey Creme! I am a huge fan of soft serve so I've been excited to try this place for a while now and I'm so happy to say it did not disappoint. The soft serve is so rich and creamy without being too sweet and the addition of the honey compliments the soft serve perfectly. I got the cereal milk so mine was topped with some type of cereal that tasted like a mix of Frosted Flakes and some kind of cinnamon granola...not sure what it was but it was bomb af! Very much looking forward to trying other toppings as flavor combos!

I'd say the only downside is that it's kinda pricy for the amount of soft serve that you get but I don't mind that too much.
author: Paige M.

description: Amazing and thoughtful service. My son loves the honey cup, my husband loves the affogato cup and I love that they make the effort to use organic milk and honey as a sweetener. Tonight, the little one wanted to try the organic cotton candy cup and we were awestruck when it came out. So much fun.
author: Vicki H.

description:
Got the regular frozen yogurt with honey. It was not very good.. the frozen yogurt had no flavor at all.. I tried a sample of it, but thought I'd give it a try anyways. 
My friend also tried their new earl gray flavor. Tasted pretty good but wasn't anything special. Probably wouldn't come back.
author: Steph W.

description:
Giving this place 3 stars because there are many ice cream shops popping up along the same vein that serve similar items--milk flavored ice cream with various toppings, and I've definitely had better. I happened to be on Irving St. for dinner, and spotted Honey Creme while walking up and down the street waiting for San Tung wings. 

First impression: I was immediately drawn in by the minimalistic decor--everything was very neutral with white and wooden walls, which I appreciated. They also had a super cute rotating rainbow ice cream cone display which made for aesthetically pleasing pictures! I also was impressed with how many items were on the menu. I'm a regular at Milkcow in Fremont, which only has about 10 different topping combinations as compared to Honey Creme, which had many more. The store itself is pretty small with only one bench and no tables, so it's not really a good place to hang around with friends.

What I Ordered:

Cereal Milk: (3/5) It was okay...definitely not bad, but not noteworthy or anything. It definitely looked better than it tasted, unfortunately. The ice cream was not very sweet, which is usually a good thing for me, but it didn't taste like anything at all which was frustrating. It also melted remarkably fast! The cereal on top was a nice touch, but didn't add enough flavor to the ice cream itself. 

Service: They took my order quickly and promptly, and I didn't wait longer than 2 minutes for my dessert, which is definitely appreciated :)

Overall, it's a cute, reliable dessert place, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Stephanie N.

description:
Located two stores down from Manna, it's easily a dessert place after dinner. I went with the honeycomb soft serve and they had a special flavor of the month: milk tea. This is my first time but, I had soft serve(original flavor) at MilkCow before so I wanted another flavor. The milk tea flavor is pretty good at first, but the more I eat, the less appealing it was. It definitely tastes good with the honeycomb was it was also really waxy where it left little bits in my teeth(weird hmm). Once the honeycomb is gone, the soft serve is okay afterwards. The cup may look small, but 8oz of soft serve is a lot, easily shared with one or maybe even two others. Honey Creme is an alright place, I'd come back if I was craving soft serve. You get to take Instagrammable pics so I guess you can say it's worth it!

INSIDE:
There is a long bench right next to the window display so you can sit and enjoy your soft serve. Kind of like Tpumps with the long bench.
author: Lisa W.

description: Ordered a popcorn soft serve and affogato soft serve. Taste pretty good. The soft serve doesn't have much flavor on its own but when mixed with popcorn and caramel, it gives a sweet taste. Overall experience was great and ice was good.
author: Lily T.

description:
# 22 Honeycreme *Rod Boba SF Rating * 4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 

Honeycreme I was not expecting to review but I cruised pass the place and noticed that they sold milk tea. I asked the lone  worker if they did indeed sell the magic goods I'm exploring and she confirmed my suspicions. 

The drink itself had a stronger than normal tea taste which was not to my liking and the boba was slighly below average which caused it get a 4/4 rating in my (milk tea/boba taste 1 to 10 scale).  It registers at #22 out of 30.

Nice venue itself however.  Please see my comprehensive rankings below:
Rod M tours San Francisco in search of the BEST standard milk tea with boba. I have individual reviews for all the places listed below.  Check out my latest reviews for the most up to date list. 

I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Milk Tea/Boba Places in the area.

Rules: I ordered a simple milk tea with Boba (regular sweetness, ice etc.)

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #30  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. 

Rod Boba SF Rating = (Taste of Milk Tea / Taste of Tapioca Balls) on a Scale of 1 to 10 (10/10) being the best score possible
* Please note that I like my boba a little bit sweet. I don't like it too milky, too strong of a tea taste or too watery.  I prefer fresh tasting larger "boba".  Powdery drinks (those places that simply have a plastic carafe that they pour out of ) and boba that tastes "old" get docked on my rating scale.

author: Rod M.

description:
Gave this place a try after dinner with my friend. I opted for the soft serve with dark chocolate which was creamy and not overwhelmingly sweet. My friend got honey which fit perfectly with the soft ice cream. I usually don't care about ice cream but it was surprisingly good not too sweet and went well with the honey.

I highly recommend a stop in for a refresher! Sweet but not overly sugary! Just right for full filling a sweet tooth. :)
author: Lin L.

description:
Simple concept: Throw some toppings on yogurt. 

While this may seem very "been there done that", the toppings that Honey Creme offers are more unique than other yogurt dessert spots I've encountered. For one, they put a straight up HONEY COMB in your yogurt. Whuuuuut. That's new. Also, (as the name implies) they love dousing your yogurt in liquid honey as well. 

My recommendation is to try the new "Milk Tea" yogurt. I think it's far more interesting for the taste buds than the original flavor. Then top the milk tea yogurt off with these adorable chocolate beans and honey. Simple, but the milk tea yogurt gives it a little kick of flavor that makes Honey Creme more than a run of the mill fro-yo. 

Bottom Line: Classic yogurt with a flare of honey(combs) buzzzzzzzzzzzz.
author: Jaime W.

description:
I got the honey comb soft serve in a cone. There was not enough honey to go with the soft serve, so it got bland really quick because the honey gave flavor to the flavorless soft serve.

There watermelon slush bubble tea was refreshing, the pearls were warm but wasn't a problem because the cold slush made the pearls cold.
author: Sally W.

description:
Frankly, this place feels to me like more of a 3.5 star rating. 

I ordered their soft serve ice cream with the cotton candy and my friend ordered the soft serve with the honeycomb.

At first taste, I thought it was really milky and creamy. But the more I ate, the more I felt that it was sort of plain. I don't think the vanilla and the toppings were that special in flavor. In addition, the cup was pretty small for how much I really paid for it (~$5).

It's definitely worth a try, but I wish the serving size was bigger.
author: Victor L.

description: Very similar to Milk Cow in Fremont, except they have matcha ice-cream In addition to the regular. I liked that both ice-cream wasn't too sweet. It was just sweet enough. The matcha didn't have enough matcha flavor compared to other ones I've had. As for the regular flavor, it was milky enough as the one at Milk Cow. Overall it was good, but not great. If I'm in the neighborhood and it's hot out, I will definitely stop by again.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I think the place and concept is really cool, that's why I tried the place. Overall, the milk ice cream is okay. Not too sweet or not sweet at all but I keep comparing to McDonald's soft serve. Maybe I'm not use the real milk flavor. I got the honey comb flavor where you will literally get a honey comb. The amount of honey given is very little to the ice cream so I really wanted more honey to supplement the ice cream.
author: Jackie N.

description: Cute little place with unique flavors. We had the popcorn ice cream and the flavor was just right! Would definitely recommend !
author: Gwendolyn W.

description:
Ordered the Honey Comb ice cream, amazingly made! The ice cream is so creamy and delicate, I'm amazed. I also ordered the coconut pudding, it is light and fresh, perfect for summer. 

The whole atmosphere is very nice. I will definitely be returning to try their other ice creams and snacks.
author: Marisa B.

description: I tried their matcha soft serve with a honeycomb, but I got a slight hint of the matcha flavor. I was kind of underwhelmed, I liked the honey more than the ice cream itself. I'd be willing try something else on their menu if I go back.
author: Leslie S.

description: I'm going to compare the soft serve I got at this place to the soft serve I know best, $1 cones from McDonalds. Comparatively, Honey Creme has much higher quality soft serve. It tastes well made. It's creamy and milky. I got the soft serve with popcorn and it added the perfect amount of texture and flavor. However, it is pretty pricey, close to $5. Even though it is higher quality, I don't know if I'm willing to pay 5 times more. AND parking sucks in this area, so if I was craving soft serve, you'd be more likely to see me going to a drive through under those glorious golden arches.
author: Kim W.

description: Came here when they first opened. Their concept is Korean soft serve ice cream with a drizzle of honey comb on top. Ice cream are made with fresh organic milk with cream and the honey comb is sourced from US bee farms. Not much flavor in the ice cream but they don't use artificial sugar which is a good thing. The honey comb is sweet which puts the sweet into the ice cream if you take a small scoop of honey comb and combine it with a scoop of ice cream and eat it like that! My biggest thing with this shop is their "Hollow middle". The ice cream itself is in a small cup already combined with a hollow middle, there isn't much ice cream you are getting. I told them about the "hollow middle" and they said that's how the machine makes the ice cream when it comes out into the cups. Thought I should mention that so first timers will know what they're getting into. It's definitely worth a try as they have many forms of soft serve ice creams to choose from including the organic cotton candy and pop corn soft serve.
author: Annie L.

description:
5 stars for 'Gram-ability; 2 stars for creativity; 1 star for actual taste.

I got to try the original and green tea soft serve flavors. Both were underwhelming. As other reviews indicate, the yogurt is not at all tart and tastes unsweetened.

The cones looked interesting, but the honeycomb really didn't taste like much. With so many other options in the bay area, I probably won't come back.

Parking situation is always tricky in SF and this spot is no different.
author: Michelle K.

description: I got the chocolate ice cream with caramel on top. I thought it was just basic plain ice cream. It was just instagram and snapchat worthy. The store is cute itself. It was $5.00 for one small cup. I don't think it was worth it. I rather go to Let's Roll that is 5 blocks away from that point.
author: Julia D.

description:
Came to honey creme to see whether it was comparable to honey mee in SoCal... although presentation was similar, the taste of the organic milk soft serve is lacking in texture and taste. Like some of the reviews on here, the milk flavor tasted really bland with no milk taste whatsoever. The honeycomb was nice, but the serving size and price is not ($4.75). 

The organic mixed grain was also disappointing as well.. tasted like crushed ice cream cone.... nope. Not paying for that when i can crush my own cones and buy vanilla ice cream from elsewhere.

Will definitely try the other flavors, but not anytime soon.
author: Samantha W.

description: My favorite spot for ice cream after dinner or grapefruit tea when my coworkers and I need a break.
author: Paty V.

description: I loved the delicate sweetness of the honey with the smooth creaminess of the ice cream. T'was was one of the best combos i've ever had and is my favorite ice cream of the moment. PS to avoid the uber sweetness from the honeycomb topping if you were to just eat it on its own, i recommend taking a smidgen of honey with each bite of ice cream.
author: P C.

description:
It's just soft serve ice cream with some toppings, but I really like this place. I've been coming back ever since I first tried it. If you ever tried Milk Cow in Fremont, it's very similar to that. Honey Creme is a lot cleaner and they take their time making the soft serve so it's not served messy. 
Their soft serve with honey comb looks really yummy in pictures but the texture is hard and I didn't like the beeswax taste. The cotton candy with soft serve is alright, nothing special. 
I would only recommend the soft serve with honey in a cup or cone, but I prefer the cone the best. I love how they swirl extra honey in the cone, so it's not all just soft serve once you reach the cone. I also love how it comes with a piece of thin cardboard to stop the ice cream or honey from dripping onto your hand. There's something special about the honey that makes me come back; I love the taste.
author: Kristin H.

description: This place is very artsy but the actual ice cream is alright. The honeycomb is fun to eat and have but it isn't enough for the whole ice cream. I got the matcha and it doesn't taste like a strong matcha. All of the flavors are very mild. With all the pictures I thought that it would be bigger but in real lift the cup is smaller than my hand.
author: Samantha W.

description:
The pictures are pretty, but for me, the taste did not really match up! I tried Honey Creme on a whim with a few friends since we dined next door at Manna. I got the soft serve with honeycomb, my friend got it with chocolate, and my other friend got it with honey. 

I would definitely recommend getting the chocolate and/or the honey. The honeycomb, while pretty, was not my fave because I didn't really like the beeswax feel or taste... It was too hard and I felt like I wasn't meant to ingest that. We saw people after us order the soft serve with chocolate and honey, and I can see how that would be a good idea. You definitely need toppings for the soft serve though! It sort of just tastes like frozen cream. Maybe a little more sugar, or vanilla..?
author: Tara A.

description:
I told my sister I wanted an "instagrammable day in the city." This was our first stop - because what Instagram account would be complete without a picture of something unexpected atop your ice cream. 

The ice cream itself was good, but not amazing. It was dense and lightly sweetened, and I appreciated the accompaniment of real honeycomb (my dentist did not). The cotton candy was a fun touch, but made it difficult to eat the ice cream from the small cup beneath. Overall, while amused by the concept, I thought my order (plain soft ice cream, with honeycomb topping and cotton candy) lacked flavor. Perhaps getting the chocolate syrup or affogato would have better piqued my taste buds.

Tip: You can add cotton candy to any cup (at additional cost of course). The menu implies you have to get the plain cup if you want cotton candy.
author: Vivian N.

description: I was entirely way too underwhelmed by this ice cream. I usually love soft serve and just wanted a little something sweet for a night cap, but this ice cream wasn't really sweet, it wasn't really anything. It was very bland, and at $4.50 a pop, I would have rather gone to the market down the street and bought a box of it's it's instead. Save yourself the trip and head to Hometown instead or even Easy Breezy or Let's Roll. All of these are better choices and more worth the $$$
author: Anna P.

description: This is probably my brother's favorite dessert place to go to because of his obsession for soft serve drizzled in honey. But I don't mind going with him as I love this stuff too! It's super creamy compared to the Costco very berry sundae. I wish they had a bigger size because we can never get enough of the soft serve! I highly recommend the soft serve with honey - very simple but delicious. You also get a stamp card for each order.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Why is there not a line out the door?? These custom made little gems of organic soft serve ice cream with unique toppings and swirls are amazingly delicious. They are not your typical American gargantuan, but just the right size to enjoy. 
   Being the first time there, I asked for recommendations. They told me which were the most popular choices. I chose the chocolate Himalayan Salt Dark Chocolate and the Cereal Grain. The chocolate on top froze into candy like those swirl toppings that crack with your spoon when you go for a scoop-yum! while the chocolate swirled around the cup stayed soft and swirled into the ice cream. My husband, little daughter and I could not stop sharing the two until they were all gone. If this place were closer to home, it'd be my first choice for ice cream, over fancier places like Ici or Smitten! The combinations of flavor with texture are just delicious. It is NOT dairy queen, like another reviewer said. This is gourmet soft serve!
author: Helen L.

description:
We went to Honey Creme around 4:30pm on Black Friday 11/25, and ordered the seasonal offering of the coffee milk tea and with the employee's friendly suggestion, chose the dark chocolate as our topping, since they did not have tapioca available.

The flavor was very light in coffee flavor, so those that are a lover of coffee may be a bit disappointed, but it may be better than choosing original, which it looks like some people are not a fan of because of the lack of flavor.  The dark chocolate gave it a little more depth of flavor and the bottom, which is where I was holding the cup, had more of the melted chocolate. It wasn't very creamy and we quickly finished the small cup.

Wait time was non-existent since there was no one inside the store other than one employee.

Price: $4.50 for a pretty small cup.

Would I come back? Probably not since it wasn't that flavorful...

Rating: 2.5 stars out of 5 for OK flavors, cleanliness, and quick service.
author: Gilda W.

description:
Honey Creme was amazing!

Small and simple soft serve shop. 
1 flavor ice cream (2 if you include the recently added Milk Tea flavor, not sure if it will be a permanent flavor though). Several different toppings. You can add more than one as long as it will fit. I got Honeycomb and cereal topping, mine came with a real wax honeycomb, extra drizzled honey, and basic cereal on top.The soft-serve ice cream itself is NOT sweet, it really does taste like frozen milk. For me, the honey adds just the right amount of sweetness, the honeycomb broke down easily oozing out delicious honey! YUMMMMM. Cereal was a nice crunch! The size is perfect....looks small, but it's enough! My boyfriend and I shared one cup.
I will come back to visit again.

*Parking was a pain. Look out for people walking to their cars, sitting in their car or just drive a couple blocks down. No biggie.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The organic true milk soft serve is creamy, soft and not too sweet with a fun selection of toppings available. It's not that Honey Creme is bad, it's just a little boring. I've been here twice and both times, I gave up after a few scoops in because the taste is just a little bland.

I've tried the dark chocolate and popcorn topping and I have to say that the popcorn (really kettle corn) is better. I had half expected the popcorn to be stale, but it wasn't at all! 

I didn't feel that Honey Creme is worth the price. Unfortunately, I think I'll likely always walk a few blocks to go to Easy Breezy for my dessert craving instead.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
There seems to be a trade off between healthy and lots of flavor. Honey Creme serves fresh milk soft-serve ice cream topped very simply with either honey, honey comb, chocolate, espresso (affogato), organic cotton candy, popcorn, or organic grains.

I tried the soft serve ice cream topped with honey. It's definitely not overly sweet, but lightly sweetened with the honey. The flavors are very light and original and I definitely feel less guilty when eating because they are relatively healthy ingredients. 

Honey Creme is a Korean company that originated in Taiwan. They are already located in many Asian countries, but this is their first US location...in San Francisco! Most Asian desserts are not too sweet so this would fall in line with their style of desserts. It's definitely a very healthy and refreshing treat. There's not many ice cream places that keep it so simple. The shop itself is a walk-in shop with no tables or chairs, but there is a bay window for sitting. Definitely a good choice for those that like dessert yet want to keep it healthy.
author: Jean S.

description:
I'm always lured into places like this. First Milk Cow in Fremont, now this place. I went out of my way to check this place out after gallivanting in SF. Of course finding parking in the area was a BIT CHallenging. 

Mind you, it was a very hot day in SF, so I was surprised there was hardly anybody in the store. Came in and browsed their menu. After a few minutes of indecisiveness, ended up going with the original soft serve on a cone with a honey comb topping. When the lady took my order I pointed directly to the picture of the soft serve in a cone (on the placemat looking handheld menu). Ended up getting the soft serve in a cup. I was a bit disappointed when my order was up, but in the end it worked out for me. It wasn't as messy and complicated to eat...judging by how difficult it was for my friend who got it in a cone..she had it bad. lol

I was underwhelmed by the taste of the soft serve. BASIC. I think the Mcdonalds soft serve tasted better and had more flavor. The flavor was so subtle. They should call it barely honey creme ice. The honey comb did compensate for flavor with it's sweetness. But towards the end, it was just a mouthful of wax that I rendered inedible and had to spit out. For the amount I paid, I could buy a Mcdonald's soft serve almost 5 times. Why am I always lured into places like this?
author: Vicky L.

description:
Well, this place is a cute little shop on Irving St and had quite a lot of business the first time I walked past it. Seeing all the customers, I decided to try it the next time I visited the area. My friend and I visited around dinner time on a Thursday and was glad there was no line or no crowd. The staff was friendly and the venue was pretty small. There is only a tiny wooden bench area near the window. 

We ordered the Honey to share. This is basically the original frozen yogurt with honey drizzle. The honey added a nice touch, but the frozen yogurt literally had no taste whatsoever. Compared to Milkcow in Fremont, Honey Creme is a bit lacking. It was a nice and refreshing cup of frozen yogurt but I wouldn't come back again. The flavor could use some improvement!
author: Catherine S.

description:
I was craving soft serve so I found that honey creme was near by and I decided to give it a try.  It's pretty similar to Milk Cow in Fremont. It was a cold day so there wasn't anyone in the store so no line. The cashier was really nice and presented me with a menu when I walked in.  I wanted the honey comb but I also wanted some chocolate syrup so the ice cream wouldn't be so bland because I felt if I just got the honey comb it wouldn't be enough for all the ice cream in the cup.

I got the chocolate syrup with a honey comb (To add a honey comb to your ice cream it's an extra $1)  So I paid $5 for a small cup of ice cream which was pretty expensive. The honey comb itself is good and is filled with honey but the only problem is you have to spit out the wax every time you bite into it. I think the soft serve could have had more flavor in it.  It was tasteless to me without the honey or the chocolate. 

Overall this place is just okay but if you're in the area and never tried honey with your ice cream I would say to check it out.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Slightly different from standard US fro-yo flavors. The original tastes like plain greek yogurt in ice cream form. How is that? Cuz the recipe is Taiwaneezy, fo-sheezy. 

For real though, straight from the website:
"Genuine Taiwan fresh-milk and dense whipping cream are the key ingredients in this fabulous Honey Creme recipe, making the ice cream soft and delicious."

Wa-Boom. There you go. I got the most popular flavor- Honey Comb (basically original w/ a chunk of honey comb). The honey complimented the plain flavor. For those who want to taste the rainbow, there are lots of topping options- cotton candy, boba, churros, cookies, etc. 

I like fro-yo. I like trying new things. And my taste buds skew toward Asian flavors, so I can appreciate this place.

PS- For the millennials, this fro-yo is hella instagrammable. #nom
author: Joanna L.

description:
Since its been super hot lately, I finally tried Honey Creme and thought it was good but not something to crave or go out of your way for. 

For starters, 4.50 for vanilla ice cream plus toppings is not worth it for the taste and size, but totally worth it for pictures and for that yummy honey flavor. I am a huge honey fan, so I ordered the mixed grains and regular honey comb flavor. 

The mixed grains has a lot of honey and texture to it so I highly suggest getting this. Their honey combs are good but have a waxy after taste! It's also an extra dollar to add a honey comb to your order of it doesn't come with it already. Compared to other dessert places, their Creme is very light and you can make it sweet by ordering the popcorn, coffee, or other flavors with it. If you order something more simple, you'll be left with just vanilla ice cream. So I suggest getting whatever has the most honey and toppings to treat yourself!!!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
This place is worth the pain of parking! Though at close to $5 or $5+ per treat, this is definitely a treat. 

My friend and I shared a cup of their honey flavor and added their organic cotton candy for $0.75 extra. I was quite surprised to see how tiny the cup was. However, one cup was plenty for the two of us! I wouldn't be able to finish one on my own! I loved the taste of the honey. Tasted light and fresh! The milk and cotton candy were also delicious!

It's a really tiny place with just one windowsill to sit. They should expand and add more seating with the amount of business they have. Just one person taking orders and one person crafting so you may want to be patient. Will definitely be back to try their popcorn and organic mixed grains flavors!
author: Kristi T.

description:
With astronomically high rent these days, San Francisco businesses have to be creative in creating a product that's cheap to make with a good ROI.

Although a Korean and Taiwanese franchise, Honey Creme is damn smart. 

Here's what $5 will get you:

A cutesy instagrammable picture.

Except....

I'm a dinosaur and don't use Instagram so I got a tiny flavorless cup of creamy blandness akin to a McD $1 soft serve (as others have mentioned) sans the vanilla and sugar.

Hit it and quit it, and onto the next hype...

OTHER NOTES:
*Honey Creme's first U.S. location.
*Cute, novelty dessert item ($3.75 - $5.50) to instagram but nothing more. 
*Only one soft serve flavor available: milk. Thick, creamy consistency (melts quickly and there was a huge empty core) but taste like a plain ice cream base that someone forgot to add to. I'm a boring vanilla girl and I don't like cloyingly sweet items but this was just like eating "creamy nothingness" as another yelper had mentioned. 
*Must add toppings (honey, honeycomb, popcorn, chocolate, etc) if you want to taste anything but there wasn't enough honeycomb to evenly distribute to add some flavor. 
*For Asian soft serve ice cream, Matcha Love is infinitely better. 
*One small bench for seating.
*Difficult street parking.
*Cc's accepted.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I think Honey Creme is hyped! It's a cute concept, but not worth it for the quality and price. I'm also comparing this place to Milk Cow in Fremont, which I think has better quality soft served ice cream and is cheaper. The ice cream at Honey Cream,to me, is reminiscent of McDonald's soft serve. It lacks depth and I wouldn't really say it's milky. The toppings, like honey and cotton candy, makes up for it, slightly. I also find this expensive as they give you a small cup for $5+ dollars. At Milk Cow, for that price you can get a large cup of creamy goodness. 

This shop is pretty small and it has no seating. People end up sitting on the window sill or standing in the middle of the floor. As people kept coming in, my friend and I resorted to standing outside in the cold, with our cold desert.

Since Honey Creme is the first of its kind in the area, I think it's an OK spot to hit up if you're in the mood. My friend says there's a Milk Cow opening in Tanforan mall, so Honey Creme would have to do for now.
author: Amanda T.

description:
I've had an account for ever, but this is the first time I've felt the need to write a review. 

Every time I'm in the sunset, this is the place I crave! My regular order is the mixed grain, but I also recommend the honey, or plain if you've never had milk ice cream before. The popcorn, affogato, cotton candy, and honey comb are all beautiful, but mixed grain and honey are sooo good!

Their milk ice cream is smooth, creamy, and not too sweet. Ask to taste their matcha, but honestly it's just not as good as the amazing milk. 

Service is always fast and friendly. The place is convenient and always kept clean. Also, they have stamp cards! But I wish they used fivestars. 

Highly recommend!
author: Debra F.

description:
I really don't know how I feel about this place...

On the one hand, who doesn't love honey and soft serve ice cream?

On the other hand, who would honestly pay almost $6 for honey and soft serve ice cream??

I'll just quote the boyfriend on this one: "I could make this from McDonald's ice cream and a packet of honey." (Though it won't look as hip!)
author: Lucy Z.

description:
I was super excited when this place opened and to be honest I've only been here once but it was actually pretty decent! 

I got the organic mixed grains with honey and wow! I'm surprised by how well it went together. It's true that the soft serve itself is not flavorful nor sweet, but it does have a creamy milk flavor that gets enhanced with the toppings! The mixed grains kind of tastes like sesame/ peanut powder and it gives great flavor! The honey makes it slightly sweet but not too sweet. 

My friend did get the honey one and she didn't like it because it was too simple and didn't have enough flavor for her. She kept comparing it to mcd soft serve. But I feel like you can't compare it to mcd soft serve because they have ton of artificial flavoring and it's actually really sweet. So if this tasted anything like mcd soft serve and you added honey it would be way too sweet and would taste terrible. 

Overall, I would come back again for more of the organic mixed grains soft serve and maybe to try the other ones as well. 

Total for 1: $4.50
author: Stella J.

description:
I tried this for dessert after eating at Manna nearby, and I was disappointed. I ordered the original with no toppings, but it really had no flavor. It was so whipped and airy that it just tasted more like whipped cream. I only ate a few bites and then threw it out (which I NEVER do with ice cream). 

It's a cute little space, but the prices are pretty steep if the taste isn't on par.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Reading previous reviews is rather entertaining: it ranges from complaints about the soft serve as tasteless, to relief for finally having a dessert option that's not overly sweet, to raving praise about this cute new shop, to musings pondering why people rave about Honey Creme.

As a paradoxical person who has a sweet tooth but continuously complains about desserts being too sweet, I rarely find mildly sweet desserts since evolution has shaped our population to gravitate largely towards sugar. Honey Creme satisfies my preferences, as their soft serve is deliciously more milky than sweet, well balanced between creamy and light, and notably photogenic.  

I tried the Mixed Grains, consisting of a caramel drizzle and mixed grains that I couldn't quite identify. (In any case, I can fool myself into being guilt-free for eating something called mixed grains). As many Yelpers have pointed out, there is a hollow core but I found it insignificant since the soft serve is piled so high to a decent overall portion size. The main issue I found was the heterogenity of the toppings: most of the topping/sauce was on the top and the bottom, leaving the middle largely plain. I suggest mixing it well to avoid leaving disgruntled over plain-tasting ice cream.

Prices are standard for dessert in SF, at $4.75 for a cup with topping and $5.50 for cone, and they even have a stamp card! (This is the city where $4 gets you a piece of toast or a cup of pour-over coffee.) I think I'll be sticking with the cups because I don't see anything too special about the cones, besides the colorfulness and the whimsical cone boquet decor. Along the same vein, their whole shop is clean and modern, with lots of good backgrounds for Instagrams.

I will be back to try the other flavors, especially dark chococlate since it looks like one of those sauces that solidifies. The honeycomb is popular but in my opinion it looks odd and chewy, more for the looks. I also chatted with the servers to ask about upcoming flavors, and they said they will be adding a cereal one soon and a coffee milk tea soft serve in the near future! (Another reason to come back is because this time my nails were unpainted and I forgot to wear my rings... first world problems)
author: Edna C.

description:
I really wanted to give them 5 stars, I really do! It was definitely 5 stars the first time I went at 9:30pm on a Tuesday night when there was nobody there. The soft serve was creamy, thick, rich and perfect! Honey was sweet and delicious. Totally hit the spot!

Then I went again at 6:30pm Thursday and the consistency of the soft-serve ice cream was totally whack! It was icy and melted really quickly; it did not seem like it was churned long enough in machine. Nothing makes me more disappointed than lack of consistency in a place that I initially enjoyed and icey ice-cream!

 $4.50 gets you a small cup of soft serve with honey. If you also want to add a honeycomb, its an extra $1. I recommend going just for honeycomb only or straight honey only because both can make it overly sweet. I was just too greedy.

I'm sure I will be back since I want to try the Affogato next. They brew the espresso with a Nespresso machine. Other flavors include popcorn, organic cotton candy, dark chocolate syrup, chocolate beans, and of course original. I really hope they get their consistency down!
author: Janny S.

description:
I was very excited to try this place since the Sunset area doesn't really have a soft serve place that has toppings. 

-The concept of this store is very simple: soft serve with particular toppings. I ordered the popcorn soft serve and my friend ordered the honey comb soft serve. 

I would definitely recommend you to try it if you've never been here. It'd be a pretty cool idea if they had soft serve with boba!
author: Erica K.

description:
Lots of critical reviews here, but I liked it. $4.50 for a cup of ice cream with your choice of topping. 
 
I tried the organic mixed grains and the affogato. Get the affogato if you're a coffee lover because it's topped with a shot of expresso, mmm. 

Cons: there aren't tables or seats since the place is small. Also, $4.50 is a little steep for the amount given. 

Overall, I had a great experience here. Service was good, the ice cream was delicious, and portion size was perfect- not too small and not too big.
author: Corinna T.

description:
FINALLY. Norcal is slowly catching up to Socal's selection of food/desserts. From boiling point to din tai fung to 85C to potted plant milk tea and now the ever so popular raw honey with soft serve. 

Bad days call for comforting desserts. This satisfied my every craving and especially reminded me of good desserts from LA's Korea town. 

Honey creme is from South Korea and Taiwan originally. Reviews are asking, "I dont get what's so special about this" and people are wondering "what makes this different?" 
The soft serve is made with fresh milk and creme and the honey is from the bee farms. If you're not super into fresh ingredients or if you're not too big of a food critic, then yes, you really won't care so much for this. 

::Dessert::
Honey 4.50: If you dont like it too waxy/thick, this would be a better choice than honey comb. Light and refreshing. But if I'm comparing to the ones in LA, i think the soft serve was a little off. The honey was pretty good though. The first bite everything felt perfect. As I ate more and more the soft serve was not bold enough and felt a bit plain in flavor and there was definitely not enough honey. In socal, they have a whole bottle of honey  available on the counter for you to use. Overall still good though, I believe they will improve over time. 

 ::Atmosphere/Service/Parking::
The place was very clean cut and simple. There are no tables only one long bench along the window. My friend and I came on a Tuesday around 8:30pm and there weren't that many people. 
Service was good. The cashier answered all my questions. 
Parking always sucks. It's Irving. But luckily we found a spot 3 blocks down. 

Will come back to try another flavor to write a better review:) Hopefully it wont disappoint.

::Update::
Came back for the dark chocolate!
Dark Chocolate: they sprinkle the cup with chocolate syrup then add in soft serve and top it off with chocolate syrup that hardens at the top of the soft serve. Overall a pretty good combo but again, something was off with the soft serve. I came with a different friend this time and she also felt that way too.
author: Chena N.

description:
Grand opening on April 30th! I'm so glad something similar to Honeymee in SoCal opened in SF. 

This is Honey Creme's first USA location. There is only 1 flavor ice cream with assorted toppings ranging from honey, popcorn, affogato, cotton candy or dark chocolate. You either have a choice to have your soft serve ice cream in a cup or in a cone for extra ($1). There are 17 choices you can choose from. 

Honey Creme's signature is Honey Comb Soft Serve Ice Cream. Of course, I had to try the honey comb on a cone. The presentation is simple and cute! The soft serve ice cream was simply plain and smooth. The honey comb added the perfect touch of sweetness to the ice cream. Perfect for people who want to indulge ice cream but don't want all the sugar. 

No tables or much seating available, except one long bench. If this cute little shop is packed, you should probably just order your soft serve and eat it while you walk on Irving street. 

It is a bit pricey for soft serve ice cream, however I'll pay for the presentation and the delicious soft serve. 

I will definitely be back to try the other flavors. 

Welcome Honey creme!
author: Kathleen U.

description:
Delicious organic soft serve ice cream that just opened in the sunset district!

My attention went straight for the affogato (soft serve ice cream with a shot of espresso) and they perfectly complimented one another. The organic soft serve had a perfect amount of sweetness and texture. The only complaint is that I didn't have more!

I couldn't stop thinking about it and took my friends there the following day. I had their soft serve with honey and it was super delicious! I would highly recommend Honey Creme!
author: Linda K.

description:
Today was their grand opening and since I've never actually tried the whole "Milk and Honey" combo before I thought to give it a try! It's finally made it's way to the bay!

ICE CREAM:
They serve only 1 flavor ice cream with a variety of toppings - majority honey themed (obviously). You have the option of either eating your ice cream in a cup or cone (+$1). The presentation is quite simple and nice. The ice cream itself tasted like heavy whipped cream but in ice cream form - in a good way. 

We got the ice cream in a cup with organic grains and honey. I liked how they add honey and grains at the bottom and the middle of the ice cream so you get a mix of everything. They were pretty stingy on the honey and no surprise there was a gap in the middle of the ice cream.   

FYI, the ice cream in a cup is way smaller than it looks - mini Starbucks cup status. 

SERVICE:
I had a lot of questions and the cashier was really nice and answered everything :) Since there was no one waiting in front of us, our order came out within 2 mins. 

AMBIANCE:
Very clean and brightly lit. There's only 1 long bench for seating and no tables, so be prepared to order and go elsewhere to enjoy your ice cream! 

Overall, love that this whole milk and honey thing has made it's way to the bay, and definitely want to try other place now, so I can compare and contrast. It's a bit pricey in my opinion for the amount you get, but I will be coming back to try their other flavors!
author: Samantha F.

description:
Meh.  Soft serve is crazy popular in Asia and when I heard that Honey Creme is opening their first US location and in my hometown out of all places, I was thrilled!!  While service was friendly, their soft serve did not blow me away as I had expected.

Don't get me wrong, the soft serve itself was indeed velvety smooth.  You can taste the quality in each cup but at the price point they are charging and for the size, I won't go out of my way to come back.  We got ours in a cup and unfortunately, the core was hollow, leaving plenty of room for them to pack more.  One flavor that I did not get to order but noticed that they weren't skimpy about their ingredients is their affogato.  Off to the side, they were making shots of espresso out of their nespresso machine and if you like drinking nespresso drinks, you also know that those pods itself can be quite costly.

I welcome them to the neighborhood wholeheartedly as it's always nice seeing new additions in the Sunset.  If I'm in the area for dinner, sure, I'd probably be back to check out some of their other toppings.  However, they definitely have some tough competitors within a 2 block radius.  For some crazy reason, more and more froyo, ice creamery, and sundae shops are popping up in the upper Irving area so being the newbie in the neighborhood, I fear that they will have to creative with their marketing to keep the steady flow of customers from returning once the grand opening novelty wears off.  I heard they were offering BOGO coupons but yesterday when we were there, we got a free cotton candy coupon for the next visit instead.

Granted yesterday was their soft opening, their seating/ventilation can be improved.  It was a hotter than usual day in SF but it felt like an oven inside Honey Creme.  Many folks ended up spilling onto the sidewalk outside since they could not bear the hot heat inside the store.  Not to pick on the design/spacing of the store itself, but I wished the space was better utilized for customers to have a seat/table and enjoy their soft serve while inside the store.  By the front window, there's a long bench (no tables) that strangers are sitting up close and right next to one another enjoying their soft serve.  Maybe a counter w/ chairs or stools for that area would have been better suited?  Or, break up the bench by adding some tables?  Just some thoughts but I am sure they will continue to improve as they settle into their space.  

Bonus: they do offer a frequent buyer/stamp card so definitely make sure you get your stamps for each order! :)  Cash only for now too.
author: Janetto L.

description:
Plain and pretty plain soft serve is now becoming the hype ever since instagramming your food became a thing. It seems places like Honeymee in LA and Milkcow in Melbourne are starting to pop up and this is the first place in SF with it. 

I came here on a cold foggy Monday with another friend and I got the organic mixed grains soft serve while my friend got his as an affogato style. It's a good simple dessert perfect for winding down after a meal, but something I don't think I could eat all the time. I think what I like most about these desserts are the simplicity of it; it isn't overwhelming and something that  you can take your time eating (unless you don't mind brain freeze!). Each soft-serve is between $3-5 which is typical of one of these specialty places.

I'll be back to try something different! It's inexpensive and gets the dessert job done. I think it's interesting they opened in this area because they're competing for dessert business with Holy Gelato, SF Hometown Creamery and Easy Breezy. Hopefully they're able to stick around!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
I mainly come here for the boba. To me it has the best boba in the city. They only have around 10 options but they are all superb!! I've never had a better jasmine green tea than here. Their fruity ones are really good too like the lychee and strawberry. The boba is the right texture and sweet. 

The creme is pretty milky and not super sweet, but if you get it with honey or the honey comb it's a perfect combo!
author: Monica E.

description:
This place is pretty interesting. Organic soft serve ice cream with honeycomb?? Who would've thought! 

Parking - it may be a little tough since it's a busy street. There's metered street parking as well as residential. 

Service - they were great! Greeted at the line with menus. Very friendly and they even replaced the honeycomb that fell off my cone with no hesitation! 

Food - 
Honeycomb cone - I thought it was pretty good! Presentation was nice and the paper that's on the cone makes it way easier to eat. The organic soft serve itself was crisp and light. Definitely very refreshing. There was also a piece of honeycomb on there with some drizzled honey. The honey tastes great with the soft serve but I would say the honeycomb itself was overwhelming. The piece was so sweet on its own but too small to bite into smaller pieces. It would be cool if the honeycomb pieces could be broken down to chunks. 

Not in a hurry to come back but if I'm in the area, don't mind if I do!
author: Coco L.

description:
New Korean soft serve joint in San Francisco!

Parking is located all on the streets and metered till 6pm or you can just try to find parking around the residential areas. 

The inside of this place is definitely clean and inviting. They have a "bouquet" of cones near the front door and it's a pretty nice thing to look at, lol. The menu is on the wall ahead of you but they also have menus to hand out in case you can't see too far. They have cups and they have cones and it all comes down to what you would rather have on your soft serve. My friend and I opted for the cone as a base and she got it with the honeycomb while I got mine with a honey drizzle. Together the total was around $10 and one downside to them right now is that they are currently cash only. There's a Bank of America across the street, though, if that helps. 

Service here was friendly. The cashier handed us a menu when we came in and they even replaced the honeycomb after my friend dropped hers on the floor. 

Overall, I thought presentation was lovely. I was excited about eating it and the soft serve wasn't overly sweet and tasted refreshing. The cone itself was interesting. Whereas most cones that come with ice cream don't really taste like anything, theirs tasted sorta sweet even without the soft serve. Honey was sort of disappointing. It doesn't melt in your mouth and instead just stays as a clump in your mouth. And it's honestly sort of pricey for what you get, but oh well.. It's San Francisco.
author: Venus L.

description:
Not sure what they put in their soft serve, but it's definitely tastier than most. Saw this place trending all over Instagram one day and decided to give it a try. 

The SO and I came on a Sunday afternoon and there wasn't much of a line. It's definitely a small no frills place -- just get your ice cream and walk around or eat outside, no seating room inside. Their menu looks like it's still being developed (e.g. they have cereal milk ice cream featured but apparently it'll come in the next few months) but for now, there are still about 20 different topping options for your soft serve.

Prices are definitely high, but I guess everything in SF is expensive these days. I paid about $4 for a cup of ice cream -- they also have loyalty cards and wily cashiers who were quite the smooth talker in encouraging me to come again in the future.

I kept it pretty simple and just got a honey soft serve. Their soft serve really is something special -- it's not too sweet, they nail the texture, and there's something in it that honestly just makes it taste better. It's not the shitty soft serve you get elsewhere, and I actually prefer it much more than Gott's soft serve which is one of my other favorite places. 

If you like honey, I think the honey option is actually tastier than the honey comb -- I noticed other people only getting one little honey comb, which I guess is a burst of honey, but I appreciated that they thoughtfully drizzled the inside and outside of my soft serve as to properly coat it with honey. Really yummy subtle flavors. 

tldr; pretty good soft serve, will likely be back -- definitely of higher quality than other places
author: Jasmine X.

description:
I'm a honey fanatic so I knew I had to try this Taiwanese frozen yogurt spot as soon as I saw the sign. Turns out, it's really more about the creme than the honey. After getting some recommendations from the very friendly people behind the counter, I went with the honeycomb. I guess I had an incorrect idea of what to expect because I was expecting that kind of crumbly, melt in your mouth honey comb that I've had before, but this was just a hunk of waxy honeycomb which I didn't end up eating (not even sure if you're supposed to) because I felt like I was chewing on a candle. Also, I guess I thought they would have drizzled some more honey on the froyo itself, but they didn't (there is another flavor option that's just honey drizzled over), so my dessert really didn't have a ton of flavor.
